image.altText: A composite of images of a young and old Mick Doleman and a shipwreck under the ocean.

items.synopsis: The wreck of the Blythe Star is located almost 50 years after it sank off the Tasmanian coast, its crew believed dead — until, astonishingly, they appeared out of the bush far from where the ship sank.

title.children: The crew of the Blythe Star were thought lost at sea. So why did they stumble out of a forest?

image.altText: A sign shows a red scull and bones and reads "contaminated".

items.synopsis: The Commonwealth has stopped short of admitting liability in a class action settlement, that will see  $132.7 million split among 30,000 claimants who have suffered from toxic PFAS contamination from firefighting foam.

title.children: 30,000 claimants to share $132.7m payout after Commonwealth settles PFAS class action

image.altText: Sophie and Jasmina wearing white dresses with large pregnant bellies, smiling, garden behind.

items.synopsis: Michelle and Jono Harley always dreamed of having a family — their devastating fertility journey took a twist when relatives stepped in with an extraordinary back-up plan.

title.children: The grandma, the aunt and the extraordinary back-up plan that made two babies

image.altText: A woman and a man near Ayers Rock in Northern territory.

items.synopsis: Julie Schutt, who was missing in regional South Australia for a week, had not had any food or water in all the time she was missing, her brother says.

title.children: 'She was on her last legs': Missing Queensland woman was making way to a farmhouse when she was found

image.altText: Online scam

items.synopsis: A national anti-scams centre is being established to help combat scams and online fraud, after Australians reported losing billions of dollars to fraudsters last year.

title.children: 'Hit squad' to target fraudsters as part of $86m national anti-scam effort

image.altText: people standing outside an apartment block waiting to view it as a rent sign stands on the footpath

items.synopsis: The tax office says it is cracking down on landlords who are over-claiming tax deductions.

title.children: Got a rental property, rent out your home on Airbnb or claim work expenses? ATO is focusing on you this tax time

image.altText: The first man has a tattoos on his face, the middle dark hair and beard, the third has receding dark hair & a moustache.

items.synopsis: A major manhunt is underway for a man who disappeared from the rural, low-security Palen Creek Correctional Centre with two other men yesterday afternoon.

title.children: 'Do not approach them': Police capture two men after trio escape Queensland prison

image.altText: An older white man in heavily armoured combat gear and a helmet stands on a rooftop, with a soldier looking out behind him.

items.synopsis: Today, as Russia's President Vladimir Putin flails around dispatching one failed military chief after another, Yevgeny Prigozhin — for the moment at least — is probably the safest Russian in the world, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Putin needs this man more than anyone else — until the moment he ceases to be of use

image.altText: Composite image of Pita Limjaroenrat and Paetongtarn Shinawatra.

items.synopsis: Thailand's opposition secured a stunning election outcome on Sunday, setting the stage for deal-making over the formation of a coalition government in a bid to end nearly a decade of military-backed rule.

title.children: Youth vote helps deliver stunning election result in Thailand

image.altText: Sam kerr is mid-backflip with Chelsea teammates around her after a goal in the Women's FA Cup final.

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr scores her fifth goal from the past three FA Cup finals as Chelsea beats Manchester United 1-0 in front of more than 77,000 fans at Wembley.

title.children: Record crowd packs out Wembley to watch Sam Kerr win FA Cup for Chelsea

image.altText: An external shot of a zinc factory looking up towards a blue sky and white clouds.

items.synopsis: As South Korea edges closer to being solely powered by renewables come 2050, the manufacturing industries of Australia's third-largest trading partner believe hydrogen gas is the answer to help reach its target.

title.children: Korea's demand for Australian hydrogen has never been higher. Is it the start of a new mining boom?

image.altText: An island in the distance across the water

items.synopsis: An air and sea search continues for a person still missing after authorities received a distress call from a yacht off Sandy Cape last night.

title.children: One person found, another still missing off K'gari (Fraser Island)

image.altText: A man blurry in foreground in sunglasses walks past two campaign posters for election rivals.

items.synopsis: Türkiye appears headed for a run-off presidential election, with the parties of both Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and opposition rival Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu both failing to secure 50 per cent of the vote.

title.children: Türkiye could face run-off election after tight race between President Erdoğan​​​​​​​ and Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu

image.altText: Woman sits at a desk looking at a calculator and bills, a man is standing behind her on the phone, both look stressed

items.synopsis: Core inflation has eased, yet the Reserve Bank of Australia remains like a coiled spring, ready to further raise interest rates at any moment. So, what could trigger the central bank into another increase in its cash rate? David Taylor explains.

title.children: A pay rise is a relief to many but this is what it could do to your mortgage

image.altText: Person leaning over a table wearing a hooded gown, with a box of tissues and a mug on the table.

items.synopsis: This respiratory virus is so common that most children will have had at least one infection before they turn two. Most cases are mild, but it can cause severe illness for young children, the elderly and the immunocompromised.

title.children: Australia has been counting RSV cases for less than two years. Here are the basics about the common cold virus

image.altText: Singer Kelly Clarkson poses for a portrait on the set of The Kelly Clarkson Show

items.synopsis: Singer and television personality Kelly Clarkson is at the forefront of a Rolling Stone report from early May that accused her self-titled talk show of being a toxic workplace.

title.children: Kelly Clarkson addresses allegations of a ‘toxic workplace’ on her talk show

image.altText: Light shines through a window onto a man wearing a blue jumper and glasses.

items.synopsis: Residents in a riverside retirement village that flooded last October, extensively damaging dozens of homes, say they were staggered to learn the village had a limit of $5 million for flood insurance.

title.children: 'We built on a swamp': Flood insurance at disaster-struck retirement village had $5 million limit

image.altText: A line stretches back as far as the eye can see outside Centrelink.

items.synopsis: You can define a "recession" in different ways. Are we experiencing one now? asks Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: What is a recession? Are we experiencing one now?

image.altText: Kevin Sinfield carries Rob Burrow over the line at the Leeds Marathon.

items.synopsis: Former England rugby league teammates Kevin Sinfield and Rob Burrow raise millions of pounds for research into motor neurone disease, after Burrow's diagnosis in 2019.

title.children: Kevin Sinfield carries ex-England rugby league teammate Rob Burrow over marathon finish line, raising money to fight MND

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Linda Burney in front of the Uluru Statement

items.synopsis: We break down everything to do with the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: There's a lot of talk about a Voice to Parliament. Here's what it is and who's for and against it

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The ASX is falling as two big banks trade without rights to their latest dividend payments. NAB tips at least one more interest rate rise. Follow the day's financial news and insights from our specialist business reporters on our live blog.

title.children: ASX dips as two big banks go ex-dividend, NAB tips at least one more rate rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The yo-yo rates forecasting of NAB continues. The bank, which had pencilled in a 4.1% rate peak in February then backed away from that, eventually settling on a 3.6% RBA cash rate peak, before last month's surprise rate hike blew that out of the water. NAB has now swung back to its February forecast, and expects the Reserve Bank to push through at least one more rate rise. It has also blamed the RBA and its flip-flopping on communication for its frequently changing rate forecasts. "The key uncertainty for our rate expectations has been the reaction function of the RBA, and monetary policy strategy of the RBA been marked by some mixed signals in 2023. "However, it is clear that the near-term balance of risks on inflation remain to the upside, and the RBA is forecasting inflation to only return to the top of the target band by mid-2025. "At least one additional rate rise is likely to be necessary to limit the risk this timeline slips any further. We wouldn't rule out the prospect of an additional rise to 4.35% if the data stays stronger for longer. "Importantly, our rate call is not a response to the recent Federal Budget, which we judge to be broadly neutral in terms of its effects on inflation and implications for monetary policy." For those already struggling with rapid rate rises on large mortgages, NAB offers a glimmer of hope. "It remains our view that, as higher rates pass through to household cash flows and the wider economy, the economy will begin to slow more noticeably in the second half of 2023 and into 2024, seeing annual GDP growth slow to below 1% and the unemployment rate begin to rise, reaching around 4.7% in 2024. "This makes it an increasingly difficult balancing act for the RBA to manage inflation lower without slowing the economy too much. We continue to expect the cash rate to return to a more neutral setting of 3.1% by mid-2024 as this slowdown takes hold." So, NAB expects rates will come back down, but only after a few hundred thousand people lose their jobs. If you're not one of those people, that will be good news for keeping up with your mortgage. If you are …
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NAB warns RBA cash rate likely to hit 4.1%, possibly higher

children.content: The yo-yo rates forecasting of NAB continues.

The bank, which had pencilled in a 4.1% rate peak in February then backed away from that, eventually settling on a 3.6% RBA cash rate peak, before last month's surprise rate hike blew that out of the water.
NAB has now swung back to its February forecast, and expects the Reserve Bank to push through
at least
one more rate rise.
It has also blamed the RBA and its flip-flopping on communication for its frequently changing rate forecasts.
"The key uncertainty for our rate expectations has been the reaction function of the RBA, and monetary policy strategy of the RBA been marked by some mixed signals in 2023.
"However, it is clear that
the near-term balance of risks on inflation remain to the upside
, and the RBA is forecasting inflation to only return to the top of the target band by mid-2025.
"At least one additional rate rise is likely to be necessary to limit the risk this timeline slips any further.
We wouldn't rule out the prospect of an additional rise to 4.35% if the data stays stronger for longer
"Importantly,
our rate call is not a response to the recent Federal Budget, which we judge to be broadly neutral in terms of its effects on inflation
and implications for monetary policy."
For those already struggling with rapid rate rises on large mortgages, NAB offers a glimmer of hope.

"It remains our view that, as higher rates pass through to household cash flows and the wider economy, the economy will begin to slow more noticeably in the second half of 2023 and into 2024, seeing annual GDP growth slow to below 1% and the unemployment rate begin to rise, reaching around 4.7% in 2024.
"This makes it an increasingly difficult balancing act for the RBA to manage inflation lower without slowing the economy too much.
We continue to expect the cash rate to return to a more neutral setting of 3.1% by mid-2024
as this slowdown takes hold."
So, NAB expects rates will come back down, but only after a few hundred thousand people lose their jobs.
If you're not one of those people, that will be good news for keeping up with your mortgage. If you are …

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is down in early trade, but things aren't as bad as they look. While the ASX 200 is off 0.2% at 7,244 points and the All Ords down a similar amount at 7,439, much of the decline is down to ANZ and Macquarie. Both banks are ex-dividend today, which means anyone who buys their shares from today on won't get their most recent shareholder distributions. That's an 81-cent half-year dividend for ANZ and a $4.50 per share payment for Macquarie shareholders. That's the main reason ANZ's shares are down $1.06, or 4.3%, to $23.44, while Macquarie's are off 3%, or $5.33, to $173.75. The banking sector as a whole is a little on the nose, amid ongoing concerns about the crisis for many US regional banks, as well as more general worries about credit quality and earnings for banks with interest rates higher than they've been for more than a decade. The financial sector on the ASX 200 was down 1.2 per cent in the first 25 minutes of trade, with industrials, education and technology also stuck well in the red. On the flip side, mining and energy are having good mornings, with basic materials up 0.9 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower as ANZ and Macquarie go ex-dividend

children.content: The Australian share market is down in early trade, but things aren't as bad as they look.
While
the ASX 200 is off 0.2% at 7,244 points and the All Ords down a similar amount at 7,439
, much of the decline is down to ANZ and Macquarie.
Both banks are ex-dividend today, which means anyone who buys their shares from today on won't get their most recent shareholder distributions.
That's an 81-cent half-year dividend for ANZ and a $4.50 per share payment for Macquarie shareholders.
That's the main reason
ANZ's shares are down $1.06, or 4.3%, to $23.44, while Macquarie's are off 3%, or $5.33, to $173.75

The banking sector as a whole is a little on the nose, amid ongoing concerns about the crisis for many US regional banks, as well as more general worries about credit quality and earnings for banks with interest rates higher than they've been for more than a decade.
The financial sector on the ASX 200 was down 1.2 per cent in the first 25 minutes of trade, with
industrials, education and technology also stuck well in the red
On the flip side,
mining and energy are having good mornings
, with basic materials up 0.9 per cent.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After a pursuit over the past few months, US gold giant Newmont appears to have landed its Australian target, with Newcrest's board agreeing to back its takeover offer. In the absence of a superior proposal emerging, Newcrest's board has unanimously supported the offer that will see its shareholders receive 0.4 Newmont shares for each Newcrest share they own. Newcrest can also pay its shareholder a special franked dividend of up to $US1.10 a share prior to completion of the deal. The Australian company says the deal values Newcrest at $29.27 per share, a 30.4% premium to prior to Newmont's initial offer being made. The deal values Newcrest at an enterprise value of $28.8 billion, leaving its shareholders with a 31 per cent stake in the combined company. Newcrest says it will leave the merged company as a "clear global leader in gold production" with a significant and growing presence in copper. Aside from needing support from Newcrest shareholders, the deal will also need regulatory approvals from the Foreign Investment Review Board and other regulators in several countries.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Newcrest board backs Newmont's latest takeover offer

In the absence of a superior proposal emerging, Newcrest's board has unanimously supported the offer that will see its
shareholders receive 0.4 Newmont shares for each Newcrest share they own
Newcrest can also pay its shareholder
a special franked dividend of up to $US1.10 a share
prior to completion of the deal.
The Australian company says
the deal values Newcrest at $29.27 per share, a 30.4% premium
to prior to Newmont's initial offer being made.
The deal values
Newcrest at an enterprise value of $28.8 billion, leaving its shareholders with a 31 per cent stake
in the combined company.
Newcrest says it will leave the merged company as a "clear global leader in gold production" with a significant and growing presence in copper.
Aside from needing support from Newcrest shareholders, the deal will also need regulatory approvals from the Foreign Investment Review Board and other regulators in several countries.

image.altText: Dominic Savage, Mia Threapleton and Kate Winslet pose while holding BAFTA awards. Threapleton and WInslet share a glance.

items.synopsis: Derry Girls, Bad Sisters, The Traitors and Paddington are among the big winners at the BAFTA TV Awards in London.

title.children: Kate Winslet wins big, alongside Queen Elizabeth II and Paddington at the BAFTA TV awards

image.altText: Jason Day hugs his son as he walks off a golf course in the rain.

items.synopsis: Thirteen years after winning his maiden PGA Tour crown at the Byron Nelson, Australian Jason Day wins the Texas event again for his first victory since 2018 and 13th overall.

title.children: Jason Day ends five-year title drought at the site of his maiden triumph

image.altText: Bald man holds up photograph

items.synopsis: While the art world is grappling with the idea of artificial intelligence producing art, some artists are already creating work and controversy.

title.children: Boris Eldagsen wanted art world to discuss AI and photography — it raised even more questions

image.altText: A woman in blue scrubs in a hospital bed.

items.synopsis: Bunbury cancer survivor Fiona May thought she was peri-menopausal after doctors said she had nothing to worry about — but that changed when she collapsed while on holiday.

title.children: Fiona thought her fatigue and weight gain were early signs of menopause, then she collapsed

image.altText: Lara Alexander wears a black coat and blue and pink scarf and stands on a suburban Launceston street

items.synopsis: Newly-independent MP Lara Alexander says a "huge weight" has been lifted from her shoulders, while the Tasmanian Greens' push to axe Hobart's new stadium look set for failure without Labor's support.

title.children: MP relieved after turning independent, but hurdles ahead for now-minority government

image.altText: A composite image of Jack Riewoldt, Michael Voss and Nick Blakey

items.synopsis: An emotional rollercoaster for Carlton, Richmond party like it's 2017 and Sydney reach their tipping point in a potentially defining round nine. We digest the week that was.

title.children: AFL Round-Up: Blues' broken hearts, Tigers' greatest hits and Swans' breaking point

image.altText: One of Saturn's rings is pictured with three differently sized half moons around it.

items.synopsis: Saturn has been recrowned "moon king" after scientists discovered 62 new moons in the gas planet's surroundings, using a technique called "shift and stack", bringing the total to 145, overtaking previous record holder Jupiter, which has a mere 95 recognised moons.

title.children: Saturn reclaims its title of 'moon king' with the discovery of 62 new moons orbiting the planet

image.altText: Zoe Bettison standing behind five microphones talking

items.synopsis: For governments, social media influencers have become a communication frontline particularly as they try to connect with young people. But evaluating the success of such strategies is hard to do, writes Rory McClaren.

title.children: Influencers, TikTok and taxpayer dollars: The world of tourism marketing in the social media age

image.altText: A man in cycling gear sprays champagne from a stage.

items.synopsis: Belgian cyclist Remco Evenepoel is forced to withdraw from the Giro d'Italia after testing positive to COVID.

title.children: 'I am really sorry to be leaving': Giro d'Italia favourite pulls out of race after reclaiming pink jersey

image.altText: A woman leans against a wooden post in front of vegetation wrapped around a leaning fence.

items.synopsis: Farmer Tess Herbert says the family farm lost millions of dollars worth of crops when the town of Eugowra in the NSW central west was hit by an 'inland tsunami'.

title.children: Six months on from 'inland tsunami', community cries out for support
